												Cloudlands: VR Minigolf is aiming to be the Virtual Reality minigolf experience. Boasting a solid put mechanic, intuitive room-scale and click-to-teleport locomotion, this game is definitely up to par. I have not tried any user generated content yet, the official course has kept me more than happy. The gameplay feels very realistic, though getting your stroke down can be a bit trying as you don't have the weight of an actual club. This game delivers on the familiarity of minigolf while adding elements only available in a digital format- such as moving blocks, cannons, fans, and other obstacles that would be either impossible or impractical in the real world.Pros:+Great headtracking, room-scale, and click-to-teleport locomotion.+Official course is very well designed and a pleasure to play.+Feels like the real thing.+Pleasing visuals.+Putting is consistent once you get a feel for the motion range.Cons:-Local multiplayer is workable, but a hassle. Not really recommended as a party game since you're going to be constantly having to adjust the straps. God forbid someone is wearing glasses and you have to adjust the lenses too.-My localisation appears to be broken. I get random chinese characters on some menu elements and buttons. This is not a gamebreaking issue though since the menus are intuitive enough to guess and get by.-Would be nice if they could introduce a control mechanic to ghost/materialize your club. Theres been times where I've accidentally hit the ball while I'm just trying to look around.-Casual players can become frustrated at the difficulty of some holes, bringing down the mood of the group. Nobody likes failing infront of their friends. Know the people you're trying to play with.-Lack of weight in the controller makes getting a feel for putting more difficult than in real life.

												Note: I haven't tried the other Mini Golf game available on Steam for VR devices so I can only attest to my experience with this one. I played this with three of my friends this past weekend and had a good time with it. The local multi-player works by trading the headset off with the other players after you have completed your hole, so it doesn't require you to trade off the headset after every shot which is good because it would likely lead to a lot of fatigue and annoyance trying to put the headset on and off. Only downside to this is that you can't hit your friends golf balls when they're in your way (since the hole is finished for them) on the course which I'm sure would lead to some funny situations. The online multilayer is not available yet so I will update my review later when that is released. You can set up the course for a full 18 or a random 9. I'd recommend going for the random 9 if you have 4 people playing because it takes a long time to get through 18. We stopped after we got past the 9th hole because it was getting late (it took an hour and a half.)I haven't had the chance to check out the course editor. My biggest gripe with the game is that you can accidentally hit your ball if the club hits it as you're switching the controller over to the next player. Only advance to the next person's turn when they are fully ready. 												I do not recommend this game for several reasons.  First off, some of the courses are so ridiculously hard that there is no fun in there at all. Fourthly, when I want to hold onto my controller tightly since I want to swing hard, I inevitably hit the grip buttons, and this brings up the score card and invalidates my swing.  There is no way to disable the scorecard opening when clicking the grib buttons that I can see, so this is terribly annoying.  Lastly, there is no way that I can see that you can change the orientation, so I'm sometimes forced to stand facing a direction where my controller sometimes loses tracking.  There should be a simple way to change the orientation so I can stand facing a different direction.  Unfortunately the makers of the game decided not to give the player that opportunity.  For all of these reasons, I cannot recommend this game.  There is a lot of promise to VR mini-golf, but the developers have a lot of work to do it make it an enjoyable experience.

												I originally bought this game back in April, before I got my Vive. I refunded it after minutes of playing it. The Vive wasn't designed to spend so long staring at the ground. On top of that, graphics were flickering, and at one point, the world started twisting and swaying, forcing me to pull the headset off, and gave me a headache for 2 hours.In the Summer sale, I thought I'd try it again. After all, months later, the game may have improved.Well... no. Not really. The graphical glitches are still there, with textures visible loading in, but that's not the problem.The game, for me at least, is too faulty by design. For example, after teleporting to the ball, rather than repositioning the player in a logical position, the game simply does so based on a fixed geographical angle. By this I mean if you're facing North when you hit the ball, and the direction between the resulting shot lines the ball and the hole in a south direction... when you teleport, you'll remain facing North, rather than the game predicting where you should be standing. This means that you then have to walk around the room in a tiny circle, making sure that you, physically, are now facing the correct direction.This results in the Vive, with its tethered cables, constantly twisting up. On top of this, the number of times I accidentally touched the ball with my bat while I'm turning around, and adding to my 'score'. This could easily be prevented by having the player pull the trigger or push the touch pad to retract the club, or even require it to be held when taking a shot. Of course, this wouldn't really be an issue if they just fixed the orientation.With this in mind, swapping the headset during a multiplayer game, each turn, doubled, tripled or even quadrupled the tangling issue. After our 2 minute game, my wife and I had to spend a few minutes unravelling the headset.The fixes for these 2 issues are easy and should be obvious. A path finding system would enable the game to predict where the player would want to stand, and effectively rotate the level for them, rather than them needing to rotate so much.Order of play should be based on last on, first on. This means to say whomever has the headset on at the end of the hole gets to play the first hole on the next game. This reduces (potentially halves) the number of times the headset needs to be taken off. At the moment, the game lets whomever is winning stay on. This means that a close game makes it hard to predict who is next to play.I'll not risk my headset cabled getting damaged simply because the developers can't figure out such simple solutions.At one point, we started the game, and immediately accidently touched the ball. Even though it hadn't even left the wooden start space, it counted that as a hit. We then quit the game, and tried to start again. From here, we couldnt figure out how the change the player names. As we'd done it once before, the game didn't ask us a second time. Very frustrating. I'd like to be able to choose who goes first.Another bug bear is that the menu itself is a golf game. "Want to play? Knock the ball into this gate!" Why slow down a menu? Just allow us to point and select. I don't want to play a game so that I can play the game!Finally, the hit detection is odd. At one point, I swang the club quite fast, and it went through the ball. It moved less than an inch, but still classed it as a stroke. Add that to the fact that there didn't appear to be any music playing, and the game was more hassle than fun.

Nuff said...Long Review:Cloidlands: VR Minigolf is as close to playing real Minigolf as you're gonna get (hence the short review).Pros:It's Minigolf in VR.The distance the ball goes relative to the power in your swing feels accurate.Great graphics. The pics on the steam store page accurate.Better than real life Minigolf in the sense that if a ball is close to a wall, you can wack the ball through the wall instead of having to nudge it away.There's local and online multiplayer, a rare feature in VR games. For local multiplayer, you give the headset to someone else when it's their turn, and online multiplayer just works.Nice variety in the holes.Cons:There's only one course of 18 holes (as of the time I'm writing this). Because of this it doesn't take long to go through the entire game and there's very little replayability.No voice chat in online multiplayer. The Vive has a mic, so there's no reason it shouldn't be in there.This isn't the Devs' fault, but it's a bit odd using the Vive controler as a golf club, at least for me. Don't get me wrong, it works. It's just doesn't feel like a golf club, probably because it isn't.In Conclusion:If you love Minigolf, go ahead and buy it. If you hate Minigolf, don't buy it. If you're in the middle, I'd get it on sale. I don't think it's worth the $20 in it's current state (as of the time I'm writing this). If they add more than one course I can see people paying full price for it, but untill then I'd wait till it's on sale for $10 or so.

												2/6 update: So, the devs did fix the two-controller/one-controller issue I complained about in #2. #1 remains an issue, but I think it's down to Vive tracking precision. For example, on the first hole in the game when you play the 18 pre-built map holes, if I try to hit a hole in 1, it will often shoot off at an angle, but it's the same angle every time (either, say, 8 degrees above or below the hole. Always the exact same angle if it isn't dead on.) If I just randomly swing with one arm, not even bothering to aim, I hit a hole in one quite frequently. This could be jitter in my lighthouses, my own body, or God knows what else, but it's there and it *can* be irritating.If you really love minigolf, this will be a fun place to pop in, play a game or two, and pop out. The harder courses (like the par 74 hole, or the par 16 one) can get SUPER frustrating really quickly though, so my complaint that it can be a frustration simulator is still valid. Pick your maps carefully.Most of all, remember to keep your club head in the air when transitioning levels! That problem still remains. :/---End update---People are not kidding when they say this game is hard. I picked 'random 9', and my second course was, I♥♥♥♥♥♥you not, par 74. I ended up needing 88 strokes to finish it. When other people say the game is brutal they are NOT joking. This isn't inherently bad, so consider this a PSA.The actual bad:1. The clubface isn't straight. Or perhaps it's due to how the Vive controller is designed that you end up not hitting the ball straight. Either way, your shots will consistently go to the right of center unless you force yourself to compensate. There is no way to adjust the clubface angle to fix this.2. You need both controllers, but only control the putter with one. Anyone used to using a real putter will find it very strange to be accurate while holding the putter in just one hand. Or having a controller dangle while trying to put two hands on the single vive to simulate a normal putt. In truth, there's no reason they can't put everything on one controller. It would also be ok to add a two-handed putting mode, but I realize almost all users won't want that, so I also support that *not* being added.3. You have to hold your putting hand in the air when you start a new hole or else you might accidently send the ball flying when your putter spawns in on the new level -- right on top of the ball. The number of times I unintentionally hit the ball was SUPER iiritating, because I never accidentally hit the ball IRL like that. Just have the club wait for us to move into it on a new level spawn.The game does have good points though. The levels are complex and interesting -- things that could only exist in a video game. The levels themselves are visually interesting and of above average graphical quality (for July 2016 in VR). There is working multiplayer. There is a lot of potential for creative and challenging community maps. Overall, I feel kinda bad giving this a negative review, but the things I whine about really do need to get fixed before I consider this game as solid as something like The Lab or Pool Nation VR.
